column1: The area was originally inhabited by Muskogean-speaking peoples. The Pensacola people lived there at the time of European contact
column2: and Creek people frequently visited and traded from present-day southern Alabama and Mississippi and southeast of Louisiana . Spanish explorer Tristán de Luna founded a short-lived settlement in 1559. In 1698 the Spanish established a presidio in the area
column3: from which the modern city gradually developed. The area changed hands several times as European powers competed in North America. During Florida's British rule (1763–1781)

column1: The original inhabitants of the Pensacola Bay area were Native American peoples. At the time of European contact

column9: five of which are arranged around a central plaza. Its main occupation was from 1250 AD to 1550. It was a ceremonial center for the Pensacola people and a gateway to their society. This site would have had easy access by a dugout canoe

column1: Presidio Santa Maria de Galve (1698–1719): the presidio included fort San Carlos de Austria (east of present Fort Barrancas) and a village with church;
Presidio Isla de Santa Rosa (1722–1752): this next presidio was on western Santa Rosa Island near the site of present Fort Pickens
column2: but hurricanes battered the island in 1741 and 1752. The garrison was moved to the mainland;

column1: Presidio San Miguel de Panzacola (1754–1763): the final presidio was built about 5 miles (8 km) east of the first presidio; the present-day historic district of downtown Pensacola

column2: the Spanish ceded Florida to the British in 1763 as a result of an exchange following British victory over both France and Spain in the French and Indian War (the North American theater of the Seven Years' War)
column3: and French cession of its territories in North America. The British designated Pensacola as the capital of their new colony of West Florida. From 1763
column4: the British strengthened defenses around the mainland area of fort San Carlos de Barrancas
column5: building the Royal Navy Redoubt. George Johnstone was appointed as the first British Governor
column6: and in 1764 a colonial assembly was established. The structure of the colony was modeled after the existing British colonies in America
column8: which was based on a different structure.  West Florida was invited to send delegates to the First Continental Congress which was convened to present colonial grievances against the British Parliament to George III
column9: but along with several other colonies
column11: they declined the invitation. Once the American War of Independence had broken out
column12: the colonists remained overwhelmingly loyal to the Crown. In 1778 the Willing Expedition proceeded with a small force down the Mississippi
column14: until they were eventually defeated by a local militia. In the wake of this
column15: the area received a small number of British reinforcements.

column1: British military resources were limited and Pensacola ranked fairly low on their list of priorities.  For this reason only small token amounts of British military forces were ever sent to defend Pensacola.  This was in contrast to colonies such as South Carolina
column2: where large numbers of British soldiers were sent.  After Spain joined the American Revolution in 1779 on the side of the rebels
column3: Spanish forces captured the city in the 1781 Battle of Pensacola
column4: gaining control of West Florida. After the war
column5: the British officially ceded both West Florida and East Florida to Spain as part of the post-war peace settlement.

Weather statistics since the late 20th century have been recorded at the airport. The city has seen single digit temperatures (below −12 °C) on three occasions: 5 °F (−15 °C) on January 21
column4: 1899 and 8 °F (−13 °C) on January 11
column5: 1982. According to the Köppen Climate Classification system
column6: Pensacola has a humid subtropical climate
column8: with short
column9: mild winters and hot
column10: humid summers. Typical summer conditions have highs in the lower 90s °F (32–34 °C) and lows in the mid 70s °F (23–24 °C). Afternoon or evening thunderstorms are common during the summer months. Due partly to the coastal location
column13: when two of the first four days of the month recorded highs reaching the century mark. The highest temperature ever recorded in the city was 106 °F (41 °C) on July 14

column1: The daily average temperature in January is 51.4 °F (10.8 °C); freezing temperatures occur on an average 13.7 nights per season
column2: with the average window for freezing conditions being from December 13 to February 20. Temperatures below 20 °F (−7 °C) are very rare

column9: and the snow event previous to it occurred on February 12

column16: 2014. Pensacola was drenched by at least 20 inches of rain within a 24-hour period

column1: Pensacola and several surrounding areas were devastated by Hurricane Ivan. Pensacola was on the eastern side of the eyewall
column2: which sent a large storm surge into Escambia Bay; this destroyed most of the I-10 Escambia Bay Bridge. The storm knocked 58 spans off the eastbound and westbound bridges and misaligned another 66 spans
column3: forcing the bridge to close to traffic in both directions. The surge also destroyed the fishing bridge that spanned Pensacola Bay alongside the Phillip Beale Memorial Bridge
column4: locally known as the Three Mile Bridge.Over $6 billion in damage occurred in the metro area and more than 10
column5: 000 homes were destroyed
column6: with another 27
column7: 000 heavily damaged. NASA created a comparison image to illustrate the massive damage. Because of the widespread losses
column8: Hurricane Ivan drove up the cost of housing in the area
column9: leading to a severe shortage of affordable housing.

column2: Pensacola suffered heavy damages by Hurricane Sally. Damages in Escambia County were estimated by local officials at $29 million.

column1: The Pensacola Marathon is hosted annually on Veteran's Day weekend. The race begins and ends at Admiral Mason Park running 26.2 miles through several Pensacola neighborhoods.
The city of Pensacola utilizes a strong mayor-council form of government
column2: which was adopted in 2011 after citizens voted in 2009 to approve a new city charter. An elected mayor serves as the chief executive of the city government
column3: while a seven-member city council serves as the city's governing body. A council president is selected by the council from its members
column4: along with a vice president.

column1: City voters approved a charter amendment on June 11
column2: 2013 which eliminated the then-nine member council's two at-large seats; one seat was phased out in November 2014
column3: and the other expired in November 2016. Two additional charter amendments were approved on November 4
column4: 2014 which made the position of mayor subject to recall and provided the city council with the authority to hire staff. The current city hall was opened in 1986.
